awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Proposal: NSF-DFG Echem: Understanding the Mechanism of Urea Oxidation on Nickel-Based Electrocatalysts
awd_abstract_narration:
Urea – a common high-nitrogen chemical waste product of mammalian metabolism, and a major component of fertilizer – poses significant threat to water resources from agricultural run-off and municipal wastewater.  A promising means for removing excess urea is to oxidize it electrochemically to produce produce harmless compounds.  Urea removal processes can also be used to generate electricity and to produce hydrogen for fuel cells.  Electrochemical urea removal therefore exhibits strong potential as a transformative technology by converting a harmful waste product to the beneﬁt of society, industry, and the environment.  The project brings together researchers from the United States and Germany to apply a synergistic blend of experimental and theoretical methods to the study of electrochemical urea removal from water.  In particular, the project seeks fundamental understanding of catalytic urea oxidation that is needed to develop feasible urea removal technologies.  Effective urea removal systems are key to a large number of technological applications including municipal and agricultural wastewater treatment, remediation of fertilizer run-off, ammonia synthesis, hydrogen production, and electricity generation.  Other benefits from this project will include workforce development and educational outreach to underrepresented grade-school students. These efforts will promote increased diversity in STEM fields, a student exchange program between Germany and the US, and improved scientific literacy of the general public.

The goal of this research project is to develop comprehensive knowledge of electrochemical urea removal over nickel-based catalysts, based on experimental and theoretical research spanning molecular and device levels.  Electrochemical urea removal will be studied by density functional theory calculations, vibrationally and electronically resonant sum frequency spectroscopy, and electrochemical measurements of reaction rate and product distributions. Particular attention will be paid to the active form of the nickel oxide electrode as it exists in different phases and oxidation states depending on electrode potential and history, such as aging and preparation method. This combined electrochemical, spectroscopic, and computational approach provides insight related to catalyst structural changes and how they affect the urea reaction mechanism, reactivity, and effectiveness of nickel, nickel-iron, and nickel-chromium catalysts. The outcomes of this research will greatly advance the scientific understanding of electrochemical urea removal -- about which little is known -- and establish a foundation in the wider field of electrocatalysis regarding electrochemical reactions on oxide surfaces and on surfaces that undergo a change in oxidation state as part of the overall reaction mechanism.  Successful completion of this research will benefit society through sustainable methods for treating wastewater and agricultural run-off that will reduce demand on water supply systems and enhance the biodiversity of marine ecosystems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_div_long_name: Division of Chemical, Bioengineering, Environmental, and Transport Systems

por.por_cntn:
This project was motivated by a project at the University of Washington to develop an artificial kidney. A major technological hurdle is how to remove urea from the dialysate of an artificial kidney. One method for doing this is an electrochemical cell that uses electrical energy to oxidize urea, a process called electrooxidation. Urea electrooxidation is also important in other technologies, such as removing urea from wastewater and using urea as a source of hydrogen. This project was intended to advance the science or reactive urea removal to a level suitable for use in a variety of technologies.

Figure 1 shows an illustration of an electrochemical urea reaction cell. The figure shows the components of the cell (flow field plates, electrocatalysts, and electrolyte membrane) in a configuration that reacts urea to produce nitrogen and carbon dioxide, while also reacting water to produce hydrogen. This project focused exclusively on the reaction of urea at a nickel-based electrocatalyst.

Intellectual Merit

The main goals of this project were to understand the reaction kinetics and mechanisms of urea electrooxidation on a variety of electrocatalysts based on nickel. Nickel and nickel-containing electrocatalysts are the only ones that can oxidize urea. We investigated pure nickel, commercial nickel-chromium-molybdenum alloys, and highly porous nickel foam modified with hydrothermally grown nickel, chromium, molybdenum, manganese, and iron. The reactions were carried out in strong alkaline electrolytes, which are necessary to provide a protective oxide layer on nickel and prevent corrosion.

Urea electrooxidation depends strongly on the nature of the electrocatalyst: its chemical composition, structure and surface area, and its oxide layer. Modified nickel electrocatalysts are generally more active than a pure nickel electrocatalyst. A high surface area promotes more reaction per unit area of electrocatalyst. Reaction only proceeds on a nickel oxyhydroxide (NiOOH) layer, which exists in two different forms, labeled beta and gamma. Electrode potentials drive the reaction, and the potential must be large enough to convert the oxide layer to NiOOH for the urea reaction to occur.

The main findings of this research are:

1. Both the beta and gamma phases of NiOOH are active for urea electrooxidation, with the gamma phase being more so.

2. Commercial nickel alloys (Haynes International C-276, B-3, and G-35) are active for urea electrooxidation. The Haynes alloys were studied because of their chloride tolerance, but unfortunately, the alloys do not tolerate chloride at the conditions of reaction.

3. Nickel foam electrodes with the modifiers listed above are very active for urea electrooxidation. Each modifier produced nearly the same effect, except for nickel-manganese, which produced higher reaction rates than did the other catalysts.

4. A urea removal cell (URC) for an artificial kidney was designed based on a nickel foam catalyst with hydrothermally grown nickel to improve surface area. The URC in this design has a volume of approximately two liters and would be suitable for use in a portable dialysis system that could be used at bedside, in a backpack, or in a rolling suitcase.

5. Only 20-40% of urea reacts to form nitrogen and carbon dioxide. The remaining amount forms byproducts that include nitrates, nitrites, cyanates, and isocyanates. These species are toxic and could preclude the use of an electrochemical urea removal cell unless a set of reaction conditions and the right electrocatalyst can be found to reduce the byproducts. This is a subject for further research.

6. Nickel phosphide electrodes are nearly 100% effective in converting nitrate ions to ammonia, which is useful for upcycling wastewater to ammonia.

Broader Impacts

More people die of kidney disease each year than of breast cancer and prostate cancer combined. Kidney disease and diabetes leads to kidney failure, which must be treated with dialysis. An artificial kidney would greatly improve the quality of life for people on dialysis. Figure 2 shows the urea removal system for an artificial kidney. The patient (left) is connected to a dialyzer and URC system (upper middle). A microscope image of the nickel foam catalyst is shown at upper right at low resolution and at lower right at high resolution. The design figure of merit is shown at lower middle.

This project supported two doctoral students who now work at Sound Grid Partners, a company that develops local electric grids powered by renewable energy, and Trinity Consultants, a company that evaluates environmental impacts of industrial and commercial projects.

This was a collaborative project involving Oregon State University (Prof. Líney Árnadóttir) and the University of Duisberg-Essen (Prof. R. Kramer Campen) and jointly funded by the Deutsche Forschungsgemeinschaft (DFG).

 


Last Modified: 11/26/2024
Modified by: Eric M Stuve

Images (1 of )
  • Figure 1. Illustration of components of a urea reaction cell to make hydrogen. Urea and water react on a nickel electrocatalyst at the anode to form nitrogen and carbon dioxide. Water reacts on a platinum electrocatalyst (not shown) at the cathode to make hydrogen.
    Eric M. Stuve
    Copyrighted
    Eric M Stuve
    Urea reaction cell
  • Figure 2. Illustration of patient connected to an artificial kidney. Clockwise from left: patient, dialyzer, urea removal cell, low resolution image of Ni foam electrocatalyst, high resolution image of Ni foam with hydrothermally grown Ni, and figure of merit for the design.
    Anthony R. Pyka
    Copyrighted
    Eric M Stuve
    Urea removal in artificial kidney
